publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... may I always be without negligence towards all virtues, having indefatigable energy in order to destroy ...! May I through the Priyavarga be able to remove the love for the life [and] the body forever!
What[ever] little sorrow [it] is, its cause [is] all clinging. May I always know this! 12. May I through the writing of this jewel of a Śīlavarga, [which is] like a diadem of instruction,
observe more than [my own] life all rules of good conduct, one by one. May I not let go the sevenfold conduct of life, even [when] separated from the Omniscient!
Mehr als das [eigene] Leben möchte ich fortwährend die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens ganz bewahren.
More than [my own] life, may I keep the rules of moral conduct entirely at all times.
May I observe the way of the ten actions; may I make [it] descend onto others. 13. May I through the writing of the excellent Sucaritavarga
be standing on precisley that. May I with body, speech [and] mind always refrain carefully from bad conduct! May I always be without harm towards all beings with body, speech [and] mind!
Mit Körper, Wort [und] Denken möchte ich mich stets sorgfältig von dem schlechten Wandel zurückhalten [wtl. beherrschen].
With body, speech [and] thought, may I at all times refrain [lit. control myself] from bad conduct.

May I reach the place of extinction that has been made known by the king of the Ṛṣis together with someone dear to him! 14. May through the writing of the Vācavarga never go out from my mouth untrue speech
Durch das Schreiben des Vācavarga möge mir niemals ein Lügenwort (aus) dem Munde herausgehen, durch das ich mich selbst zerstören oder einem anderen Schädigung bringen könnte.
By writing the Vācavarga, may no word of falsehood ever leave my mouth, by which I could destroy myself or inflict damage on someone else.
by which I might destroy myself or bring harm upon someone else. And may I not with irritated mind say any word that [would] not [be] approved of by the good ones!

May those who have been born in the hells because of untrue speech be redeemed! 15. I have written the Karmavarga – may I always be conscious of cause [and] effect! The fruit of an act, even a fine one, even a little one,

Den Karmavarga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Der Ursache [und] Wirkung möchte ich stets eingedenk sein. [Mag] sie [scil. die Tat] auch klein [und] auch gering [sein], die Frucht der Tat geht nicht zugrunde, dies möchte ich immer erkennen. In allen Geburten, zu allen Zeiten möchte sich mein Denken von den bösen Taten abwenden.

The Karmavarga I have written [wishing]: May I always be conscious of cause [and] effect. Even if it [i.e. the deed] [be] small [and] even [if it be] slight, the fruit of the deed never perishes, may I always know this. In all births, at all times, may my thought always turn away from the evil deeds.
does not disappear – may I always know that! May my spirit in all births [and] in all times turn away from evil deeds! Even in the other world
there is nothing more [important] than the deed – may the beings know [it]! 16. May I by the jewel of a Śraddhāvarga obtain this fruit for sure in all births: May I always have strong faith
in the deed, good or bad. May I seize the shame [and] modesty praised by the wise [and] dear to the good. May I always have the consciousness [that is] (permanently?) dressed in good conduct

[and] directed towards the law. 17. May I through the writing of this excellent Śramaṇavarga destroy the passion of thirst! (May I recognise the fault in the cauldron of clinging to) turning the [cycle of] birth!

p.note: The diphthong ai is consistently written ‹aiy› before k: a2-3 paiykal(ñ)esa; a4 paiykalyñesa; a6 paiykalñesa; a6 waiyke; b1-2 waiyk(e); b2 paiykāmai. The only exception is b6 (p)elaikne. Remarkable is further the ly in b4 wnolymi. Virāma is lacking a couple of times; see the metrical analysis above.
Lines a1-b6, i.e. the whole leaf, correspond to a1-b5; lines b5-6 correspond to a1-2.

The text is written in a metre of 4x18 syllables, divided 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 4; each unit of 7 can be further subdivided into 4 + 3 syllables. This leaf comprises pādas 12a–18b. [a1]¦ (s)n(ai)-(y)k(orñe) ñäś ṣek tākoym ¦ po krentaunaścä : [12a] ekwalatte-tsirauñe ¦ nautässi – – – – mñen= ¦ āsa (wa)rñai : [12b] priyavārgsa larauñe ¦ śaul kektsenn(e) [a2] (ynau)ṣk(a) ra ¦ cämpim muṣsi [12c] kuse cek warñai lakle ste ¦ tuntse ṣarm po eṅkalyñe ¦ te ṣek karsoym • (1)2mahūr ram no śāsantse ¦ śilavārgṣe naumye ce ¦ paiyka[a3]l(y)ñesa : [13a] śaultsa auṣap paṣṣīmar ¦ śīlaṣṣana sälyaino ¦ po yke postäṃ : [13b] ṣuk-yäknesa śaul-śīlo ¦ wätkau rano poyśinmeṃ ¦ mā ceu[a4] (tarko)ym : [13c] śak-karmaṣṣai ytāri tāu ¦ paṣṣimar ñiś kārpäṣṣim ¦ alyeṅkäṃnne : 13sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ ¦ paiykalyñesa tāko[a5](y)m ñ(i)ś ¦ tukne stmauwo : [14a] kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ ṣek wlāwoymar anaiśai ¦ duścaritmeṃ : [14b] snai mīyäṣlñe ṣek tākoym ¦ kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ po wno[a6]l(me)nn(e) : [14c] rṣākeṃts lānte śeśśarsoṣ ¦ yänmoym īke kekesoṣ ¦ cwī larempa : 14paiykalñesa vācavārg ¦ waiyke reki mantanta ¦ läññi-ñ (k)o[b1]ynm(e)ṃ (:) [15a] kucesa ṣañ-añmä karstoymar ¦ alyekepi kaloym wat ¦ mīyäṣṣälyñe : [15b] mamāntaṣ 〈ṣ〉pä palskosa ¦ mā ñiś reki weñim nta ¦ krentaṃts m= ārtaṣ : [15c] wai[b2]yk(e) reki ṣärmameṃ ¦ kuse tetemoṣ nraintane ¦ cai tsälponträ : 15karmavārgä paiykāmai ¦ ṣarm okone imasu ¦ ṣek ñīś tākoym : [16a] lykaśke rano to(tka) [b3] ra ¦ yāmornts= oko mā nakṣtär ¦ te ṣek karsoymä : [16b] po cmelane po preśyaṃ ¦ yāmorntameṃ yolaina ¦ klautkoy-ñä palsko : [16c] eṃṣke alyek ś(ai)[b4](ṣṣ)e(n)e ¦ yāmors= olpo mā nesäṃ ¦ karsoṃ wnolymi : 16śraddhavārgṣe naumyesa ¦ källoym oko nemcek ce ¦ po cmelane : [17a] perākäññe[b5] (mai)yyātstse ¦ ṣek ñi tākoy yāmorne ¦ kreṃnt yolaiṃ wat : [17b] papālaṣ cau aiśaumyeṃts ¦ krentaṃts lareṃ eñcīmar ¦ yase kwīpe : [17c] śīlne ausu[b6] (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e ¦ (p)elaikne ykū ime ¦ ṣek ñī tākoy 17śramaṇavārgä śpāl(m)eṃ ce ¦ (p)ai(ka)lyñesa kars(t)oym ñiś ¦ yokai kleśo : [18a] nano camel s(p)ā(rtässi) [18b] Virāma is lacking a couple of times. According to the metre, one has to read: 12a po krentaunaśc for po krentaunaścä; 15b ṣañ-añm for ṣañ-añmä; 16b karsoym for karsoymä; 16c klautkoy-ñ for klautkoy-ñä; 18a śramaṇavārg for śramaṇavārgä. In general, one can say that if an extra final syllable is metrically needed, it is mostly written ‹-o›, not ‹-ä› (13b sälyaino; 13c śīlo; 14a stmauwo; 18a kleśo). An exception is 16a karmavārgä. Not conforming to the internal 4+3 pattern of the 7-syllable unit is 14a sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ. On 17c see the text notes.
krentaunaśca: read with final a = ä instead of a because of the preceding ś (179-180). However, according to the metre one should read rather krentaunaśc\ (see below).
ñäś: this reading is the most likely, in spite of the fact that the manuscript has ñiś elsewhere.
ekwalatte-tsirauñe: a bahuvrīhi compound referring to the subject, the "I".

nautässi – – – – mñen= āsa (wa)rñai: Pinault and Malzahn (see ) restore nautässi(ś yolo śā)mñen= āsa (wa)rñai 'in order to destroy (evil) in (human) [nature] beginning with the head'. This is possible, but needs the assumption that āsa stands for āssa, a later form of āṣtsa (73, 87).

(ynau)ṣk(a): this restoration, suggested by Pinault and Malzahn (see ), is possible only if ynauṣkak, attested two times ( b3, a1), stands for /ynáwṣkak/ (not for /ynawṣkə́k/). This in turn implies that ynauṣak, attested only once ( a1), is either a reading or a writing mistake for ynauṣkak, because there is no suffix to derive /ynáwṣkak/ from **/ynawṣə́k/.
śaul-śīlo: apparently a compound.
stmauwo: w seems a correction of some other akṣara, perhaps m.
wlāwoymar: literally 'may I control myself'.
īke kekesoṣ: literally 'extinct place', here without doubt 'place of extinction'.
kekesoṣ: the transcription of №307 incorrectly has postäṃ instead (Ronald I. Kim, p.c.).
yolaina: misread as yolaine in №307.
nesaṃ: ne and saṃ seem to be corrections of other akṣaras; saṃ probably of ka.
(mai)yyātstse: b3 reads eṃṣketstse instead. The reading in №307 was not correct.

(e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e: a reading laukañe v.s. as in a1 can be excluded. If this reading is correct, the following (p)elaikne may have to be corrected into pelaiknene because of the metre (see directly below).

(p)elaikne ykū: certainly a calque, cf. Skt. dharmagata "auf den Dharma gerichtet" (II, 523b). According to the metre, (p)elaikne is to be corrected into pelaiknene (cf. a1). However, if the reading (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(tsts)e (see above) is wrong, one could also consider taking the preceding syllable syntactically with this expression, e.g. (kr)e(nt p)elaikne 'the good law'.
kars(t)oym: for this reading, cf. b5. Though illegible, a trace of the element below the ‹s› can be discerned.
yokai: missing in the transcription of №307.

list.item:
Text notes
a1. krentaunaśca: read with final a = ä instead of a because of the preceding ś ([[Peyrot 2008]]: 179-180). However, according to the metre one should read rather krentaunaśc\ (see below).
a1. ñäś: this reading is the most likely, in spite of the fact that the manuscript has ñiś elsewhere.
a1. ekwalatte-tsirauñe: a bahuvrīhi compound referring to the subject, the "I".
a1. nautässi – – – – mñen= āsa (wa)rñai: Pinault and Malzahn (see [[PK NS 28]]) restore nautässi(ś yolo śā)mñen= āsa (wa)rñai 'in order to destroy (evil) in (human) [nature] beginning with the head'. This is possible, but needs the assumption that āsa stands for āssa, a later form of āṣtsa ([[Peyrot 2008]]: 73, 87).
a2. (ynau)ṣk(a): this restoration, suggested by Pinault and Malzahn (see [[PK NS 28]]), is possible only if ynauṣkak, attested two times ([[PK NS 27]] b3, [[THT 313]] a1), stands for /ynáwṣkak/ (not for /ynawṣkə́k/). This in turn implies that ynauṣak, attested only once ([[PK AS 5B]] a1), is either a reading or a writing mistake for ynauṣkak, because there is no suffix to derive /ynáwṣkak/ from **/ynawṣə́k/.
a3. śaul-śīlo: apparently a compound.
a5. stmauwo: w seems a correction of some other akṣara, perhaps m.
a5. wlāwoymar: literally 'may I control myself'.
a6. īke kekesoṣ: literally 'extinct place', here without doubt 'place of extinction'.
a6. kekesoṣ: the transcription of [[Peyrot 2007]]: №307 incorrectly has postäṃ instead (Ronald I. Kim, p.c.).
b3. yolaina: misread as yolaine in [[Peyrot 2007]]: №307.
b4. nesaṃ: ne and saṃ seem to be corrections of other akṣaras; saṃ probably of ka.
b5. (mai)yyātstse: [[PK NS 28]] b3 reads eṃṣketstse instead. The reading in [[Peyrot 2007]]: №307 was not correct.
b6. (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e: a reading laukañe v.s. as in [[PK AS 4A]] a1 can be excluded. If this reading is correct, the following (p)elaikne may have to be corrected into pelaiknene because of the metre (see directly below).
b6. (p)elaikne ykū: certainly a calque, cf. Skt. dharmagata "auf den Dharma gerichtet" ([[SWTF]]: II, 523b). According to the metre, (p)elaikne is to be corrected into pelaiknene (cf. [[PK AS 4A]] a1). However, if the reading (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(tsts)e (see above) is wrong, one could also consider taking the preceding syllable syntactically with this expression, e.g. (kr)e(nt p)elaikne 'the good law'.
b6. kars(t)oym: for this reading, cf. [[PK NS 28]] b5. Though illegible, a trace of the element below the ‹s› can be discerned.
b6. yokai: missing in the transcription of [[Peyrot 2007]]: №307.


Metrical analysis
The text is written in a metre of 4x18 syllables, divided 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 4; each unit of 7 can be further subdivided into 4 + 3 syllables. This leaf comprises pādas 12a–18b.

[a1] ¦ (s)n(ai)-(y)k(orñe) ñäś ṣek tākoym ¦ po krentaunaścä : [12a]
ekwalatte-tsirauñe ¦ nautässi – – – – mñen= ¦ āsa (wa)rñai : [12b]
priyavārgsa larauñe ¦ śaul kektsenn(e) [a2] (ynau)ṣk(a) ra ¦ cämpim muṣsi [12c]
kuse cek warñai lakle ste ¦ tuntse ṣarm po eṅkalyñe ¦ te ṣek karsoym • (1)2
mahūr ram no śāsantse ¦ śilavārgṣe naumye ce ¦ paiyka[a3]l(y)ñesa : [13a]
śaultsa auṣap paṣṣīmar ¦ śīlaṣṣana sälyaino ¦ po yke postäṃ : [13b]
ṣuk-yäknesa śaul-śīlo ¦ wätkau rano poyśinmeṃ ¦ mā ceu [a4] (tarko)ym : [13c]
śak-karmaṣṣai ytāri tāu ¦ paṣṣimar ñiś kārpäṣṣim ¦ alyeṅkäṃnne : 13
sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ ¦ paiykalyñesa tāko[a5](y)m ñ(i)ś ¦ tukne stmauwo : [14a]
kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ ṣek wlāwoymar anaiśai ¦ duścaritmeṃ : [14b]
snai mīyäṣlñe ṣek tākoym ¦ kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ po wno[a6]l(me)nn(e) : [14c]
rṣākeṃts lānte śeśśarsoṣ ¦ yänmoym īke kekesoṣ ¦ cwī larempa : 14
paiykalñesa vācavārg ¦ waiyke reki mantanta ¦ läññi-ñ (k)o[b1]ynm(e)ṃ (:) [15a]
kucesa ṣañ-añmä karstoymar ¦ alyekepi kaloym wat ¦ mīyäṣṣälyñe : [15b]
mamāntaṣ 〈ṣ〉pä palskosa ¦ mā ñiś reki weñim nta ¦ krentaṃts m= ārtaṣ : [15c]
wai[b2]yk(e) reki ṣärmameṃ ¦ kuse tetemoṣ nraintane ¦ cai tsälponträ : 15
karmavārgä paiykāmai ¦ ṣarm okone imasu ¦ ṣek ñīś tākoym : [16a]
lykaśke rano to(tka) [b3] ra ¦ yāmornts= oko mā nakṣtär ¦ te ṣek karsoymä : [16b]
po cmelane po preśyaṃ ¦ yāmorntameṃ yolaina ¦ klautkoy-ñä palsko : [16c]
eṃṣke alyek ś(ai)[b4](ṣṣ)e(n)e ¦ yāmors= olpo mā nesäṃ ¦ karsoṃ wnolymi : 16
śraddhavārgṣe naumyesa ¦ källoym oko nemcek ce ¦ po cmelane : [17a]
perākäññe [b5] (mai)yyātstse ¦ ṣek ñi tākoy yāmorne ¦ kreṃnt yolaiṃ wat : [17b]
papālaṣ cau aiśaumyeṃts ¦ krentaṃts lareṃ eñcīmar ¦ yase kwīpe : [17c]
śīlne ausu [b6] (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e ¦ (p)elaikne ykū ime ¦ ṣek ñī tākoy 17
śramaṇavārgä śpāl(m)eṃ ce ¦ (p)ai(ka)lyñesa kars(t)oym ñiś ¦ yokai kleśo : [18a]
nano camel s(p)ā(rtässi) [18b]

Virāma is lacking a couple of times. According to the metre, one has to read:
12a po krentaunaśc for po krentaunaścä;
15b ṣañ-añm for ṣañ-añmä;
16b karsoym for karsoymä;
16c klautkoy-ñ for klautkoy-ñä;
18a śramaṇavārg for śramaṇavārgä.
In general, one can say that if an extra final syllable is metrically needed, it is mostly written ‹-o›, not ‹-ä› (13b sälyaino; 13c śīlo; 14a stmauwo; 18a kleśo). An exception is 16a karmavārgä.
Not conforming to the internal 4+3 pattern of the 7-syllable unit is 14a sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ.
On 17c see the text notes.

a1 ·[n]· ·[k]· – ñ[ä]ś[ä]\ ṣ[ek] t[ā]k[o]y_mä\ po krentauna_śc_a : ekwalatte-tsirauñe nau_t_assi – (– –) – [mñ]en= ā[sa] – rñai : priyavārgsa larauñe śaul kektse[nn]· a2 – [ṣ]k· ra [cä]mpi_m\• muṣsi k_use cek warñai lakle ste tuntse ṣarm po eṅkalyñe te ṣek karsoy[_m\ •] – [2] mahūr ram no śāsantse śilavārgṣe naumye ce paiyka a3 [l]·[ñes]a : śaultsa auṣa_p\ ○ paṣṣīma_r\ śīlaṣṣana _s_alyaino po yke pos_t_aṃ : ṣuk-yäknesa śau_l\-śīlo wätkau rano poyśinmeṃ mā ce_u a4 (–) – [y_m]ä[\] : śa_k\-karmaṣṣai ytā○ri tā_u paṣṣimar ñi_ś\ kār_p_aṣṣi_m\• alyeṅ_k_aṃnne : 10-3 sucaritavārgä\ śpālmeṃ paiykalyñesa tāko a5 ·m ñ·_ś[ä]\ tukne stmauwo : kektseñ reki palskosa ṣe_k\ wlāwoyma_r\• anaiśai duścaritmeṃ : snai mīyäṣlñe ṣek tākoy_mä\ kektseñ reki palskosa po wn[o] a6 -[l·]·[nn]· : rṣākeṃts lānte śeśśarso_ṣ\ yänmoym īke kekeso_ṣ\ cwī larempa : 10-4 paiykalñesa vācavārgä\ waiyke reki mantanta _l_aññi-ñä\ ·[o] b1 [y]nm·[ṃ] – [k_u]cesa ṣañ-añ_mä karstoyma_r\• alyekepi kaloym wa_t\ mīyä_ṣ_ṣ_alyñe : mamānta_ṣ _p_a palskosa mā ñiś reki weñim nta krentaṃts m= ārta_ṣ\• : [wai] b2 [y]k· reki _ṣ_armameṃ k_use tetemoṣ nraintane cai t_s_alpont_r_a : 10-5 karmavārgä paiykāmai ṣarm okone imasu ṣek ñīś tākoy_mä\ : lykaśke rano to (–) b3 [ra y]āmornts= oko mā na_k_ṣ_t_a_r\• ○ te ṣek karsoy_mä : po cmelane po preśyaṃ yāmorntameṃ yolaina klautkoy-ñä palsko : eṃṣke alye_k\ ś· b4 ·[e]·[e] yāmors= olpo mā ne○_s_aṃ karsoṃ wnolymi : 10-6 śraddhavārgṣe naumyesa _k_alloy_mä\ oko nemcek ce po cmelane : perā_k_aññe b5 – [y]y[āt]sts[e] ṣek ñi tākoyä\ yāmorne kreṃn_t\ yolaiṃ wa_t\ : papāla_ṣ\ cau aiśaumyeṃt[s]\ [kr]entaṃt_s\ lareṃ eñcīma_r\ yase kwīpe : śīlne au[s]u b6 ··[ṃ] ·[e] ·e ·elaikne y[k]ū-i[m]e ṣe[k] ñī tāko[y]ä\ 10-7 śramaṇavārgä śp[ā]l·eṃ ce ·ai – [l]y[ñ]e[sa] kars·oy_mä(\) ñi_ś\ yokai kleśo : nano came_l\ [s·]ā-

The diphthong ai is consistently written ‹aiy› before k: a2-3 paiykal(ñ)esa; a4 paiykalyñesa; a6 paiykalñesa; a6 waiyke; b1-2 waiyk(e); b2 paiykāmai. The only exception is b6 (p)elaikne. Remarkable is further the ly in b4 wnolymi. Virāma is lacking a couple of times; see the metrical analysis above.

%7 a1 ; (s)n(ai)(-y)k(orñe) ñäś , ṣek tākoym ; po krentaunaśc|krentaunaścä : #12a ekwalatte,-tsirauñe ; nautässi – ; – – – %2 mñen= ; āsa (wa)rñai : #12b priyavārgsa , larauñe ; śaul kektsenn(e) , a2 (ynau)ṣk(a) ra ; cämpim muṣsi #12c k_use cek warñai , lakle ste ; tuntse ṣarm po , eṅkalñe|eṅkalyñe ; te ṣek karsoym • (10-)2 #12d mahūr ram no , śāsantse ; śilavārgäṣṣe|śilavārgṣe , naumiye|naumye ce ; paikalñesa|paiyka|l(y)ñesa a3 : #13a śaultsa auṣap , paṣṣīmar ; śīlaṣṣana , sälyaiṃ|sälyaino ; po yke postäṃ : #13b ṣuk-yäknesa , śaul-śīlo ; wätkau rano , poyśinmeṃ ; mā cau|ce_u a4 (tarko)ym : #13c śak-karmaṣṣai , ytāri tā_u ; paṣṣimar ñäś|ñiś ; kārpäṣṣim , alyeṅkänne|alyeṅkäṃnne : 13 #13d sucarita,vārg śpālmeṃ ; paikalñesa|paiykalyñesa , tākoym|tāko|(y)m a5 ñäś|ñ(i)ś ; tukne stmau|stmauwo : #14a kektseñ reki , palskosa ; ṣek wlāwoymar , anaiśai ; duścaritmeṃ : #14b snai mīyäṣlñe , ṣek tākoym ; kektseñ reki , palskosa ; po onolmeṃne|wno|l(me)nn(e) a6 : #14c rṣākeṃts lānte , śeśśarsoṣ ; yänmoym īke , kekesoṣ ; cwi|cwī larempa : 14 #14d paikalñesa|paiykalñesa , vācavārg ; waike|waiyke reki , mantanta ; läññi-ñ koynmeṃ|(k)o|ynm(e)ṃ b1 (:) #15a k_ucesa ṣañ-añm|ṣañ-añmä , karstoymar ; alyekepi , kaloym wat ; mīyäṣṣälyñe : #15b mamāntaṣ «ṣ»pä , palskosa ; mā ñäś|ñiś reki , weñim nta ; krentaṃts mā|m= ārtaṣ : #15c waike|wai|yk(e) b2 reki , ṣärmameṃ ; k_use tetemoṣ , nraintane ; cai tsälpoyentär|tsälponträ : 15 #15d karmavārgä , paikāmai|paiykāmai ; b4 yāmors= olpo , mā nesäṃ ; karsoyeṃ|karsoṃ wnolymi : 16 #16d śraddhavārgäṣṣe|śraddhavārgṣe , naumiyesa|naumyesa ; källoym oko , nemcek ce ; po cmelane : #17a perākäññe , b5 (mai)yyātstse ; ṣek ñi tākoy , yāmorne ; krent|kreṃnt yolaiṃ wat : #17b papālaṣ cau , aiśaumyeṃts ; krentaṃts lareṃ , eñcīmar ; yase kwīpe : #17c śīlne ausu , b6 eṃṣketstse|(e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e ; (p)elaikne , ykū-ime ; ṣek ñī tākoy 17 #17d śramaṇavārg|śramaṇavārgä , śpāl(m)eṃ ce ; paikalñesa|(p)ai(ka)lyñesa , kars(t)oym ñäś|ñiś ; yokai kleś|kleśo : #18a nano camel , spārttässi|s(p)ā|(rtässi) ; %11 #18b
Lines a1-b6, i.e. the whole leaf, correspond to [[PK NS 28]] a1-b5; lines b5-6 correspond to [[PK AS 4A]] a1-2.

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Mehr als das [eigene] Leben möchte ich fortwährend die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens ganz bewahren. 405
a5 Mit Körper, Wort [und] Denken möchte ich mich stets sorgfältig von dem schlechten Wandel zurückhalten [wtl. beherrschen]. 307
a6-b1 Durch das Schreiben des Vācavarga möge mir niemals ein Lügenwort (aus) dem Munde herausgehen, durch das ich mich selbst zerstören oder einem anderen Schädigung bringen könnte. 313, 389-90
b2-3 Den Karmavarga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Der Ursache [und] Wirkung möchte ich stets eingedenk sein. [Mag] sie [scil. die Tat] auch klein [und] auch gering [sein], die Frucht der Tat geht nicht zugrunde, dies möchte ich immer erkennen. In allen Geburten, zu allen Zeiten möchte sich mein Denken von den bösen Taten abwenden. 452-3

a1 ... may I always be without negligence towards all virtues, having indefatigable energy in order to destroy ...! May I through the Priyavarga be able to remove the love for the life [and] the body forever! a2 What[ever] little sorrow [it] is, its cause [is] all clinging. May I always know this! 12. May I through the writing of this jewel of a Śīlavarga, [which is] like a diadem of instruction, a3 observe more than [my own] life all rules of good conduct, one by one. May I not let go the sevenfold conduct of life, even [when] separated from the Omniscient! a4 May I observe the way of the ten actions; may I make [it] descend onto others. 13. May I through the writing of the excellent Sucaritavarga a5 be standing on precisley that. May I with body, speech [and] mind always refrain carefully from bad conduct! May I always be without harm towards all beings with body, speech [and] mind! a6 May I reach the place of extinction that has been made known by the king of the Ṛṣis together with someone dear to him! 14. May through the writing of the Vācavarga never go out from my mouth untrue speech b1 by which I might destroy myself or bring harm upon someone else. And may I not with irritated mind say any word that [would] not [be] approved of by the good ones! b2 May those who have been born in the hells because of untrue speech be redeemed! 15. I have written the Karmavarga – may I always be conscious of cause [and] effect! The fruit of an act, even a fine one, even a little one, b3 does not disappear – may I always know that! May my spirit in all births [and] in all times turn away from evil deeds! Even in the other world b4 there is nothing more [important] than the deed – may the beings know [it]! 16. May I by the jewel of a Śraddhāvarga obtain this fruit for sure in all births: May I always have strong faith b5 in the deed, good or bad. May I seize the shame [and] modesty praised by the wise [and] dear to the good. May I always have the consciousness [that is] (permanently?) dressed in good conduct b6 [and] directed towards the law. 17. May I through the writing of this excellent Śramaṇavarga destroy the passion of thirst! (May I recognise the fault in the cauldron of clinging to) turning the [cycle of] birth!
